Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Small: Compliant Multifunctional Robotic Structures for Safety and Communication by Touch

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to enable better training of robots by enabling them to physically communicate via human touch using new compliant multifunctional structures. To achieve this, arrays of conducting polymers will be developed to form a system similar to the human nervous system that can sense shape and forces distributions. This sensor array will be integrated into composite foam structures using a scalable additive manufacturing process. To support development of models and to serve as proof-of-concept for these multifunctional structures on robotic platforms, simulated co-robotics experiments will be conducted using a robotic arm interacting with objects of varying compliance. Experimental details of the associated contact mechanics will be quantified in real-time using Digital Image Correlation and conventional video imaging. Output from the sensor array will then be related to shape and force distributions by solving the nonlinear inverse problem using a novel Singular Value Decomposition method. Research results will be documented and disseminated, and the experiments will be converted to STEM demonstrations targeted at educating young girls.

This research will lead to new compliant, scalable, sensing structures that simultaneously monitor in real-time both global and local shapes, as well as force distributions. Since compliant multifunctional sensing structures do not yet exist for robots, it is envisioned that the proposed work will enable realization of new bio-inspired control principles for training robots. This will significantly advance the ability to make safer interactions and decisions in co-robotics by differentiating robotic interactions with humans from other objects in their environment. The proposed integration of research and education will train new mechanical engineers to create multifunctional products that enable new products and new capabilities in existing products in critical areas such as healthcare. The new fabrication methods will enable these structures to be manufactured in the United States in a cost-competitive manner, increasing employment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As a result of htis project, we have produced 3 published journal papers, 1 submitted journal paper, and another journal paper in preparation. In addition, we have produced 3 conference papers, 1 invention disclosure, and 2 provisional patent applications. The invention disclosure and provisional patents have attracted commercialization interest from several companies in the United States and abroad. 

A total of 11 undergraduate students, 1 PhD student, and 1 Post-doc have been involved with this project. These students learned concepts in preparing nanostructured polymers, instrumenting these materials for electronic sensing, designing these materials to provide optimal transduction of deformations into electrical signals, and the design and characterization of compliant multifunctional robotic structures for contact problems. Therefore, they haave been trained to create multifunctional products in a wide variety of applications, not just robotics, but also thermal control systems and structural health monitoring.

We have also presented our research to the K-12 community through demonstrations at local schools and libraries, as well as the Maryland Day and Maryland Robotics Day sponsored by the University of Maryland and the Maryland Robotics Center. One of the robotic platforms we deployed our compliant multifuctional structures on was also profiled in USA Today by the Smithsonian Institution. A series of lecture slides have also been developed that are used in undergraduate robotics courses, such as Bio-inspired Robotics, as well as in two Research Experience in Undergraduate programs at the University of Maryland.

Technically, we have been able to develop fundamental principles using compliant multifunctional skin structures that have provided new capabilities for robots to perform communication by touch using technologies such as braille, which was profiled in one of our journal papers. Another journal paper we have submitted has provided fundamental principles for a multifunctional structural design that enables robots to distinguish between machine and human touch by using multiple sensing layers with varying compliance in the skin. The design of the skins themselves involve new materials and structural modelsm validated using 3D Digital Image Correlation (DIC) that we have detailed in the publications,  as well as details of the manufacturing methods we have developed to realize them. They also include new imaging approaches for sensing using the technique of Electrical Impedance Tomography that allows us to rapidly characterize the robot-human interactions, and to resolve details of the shapes and force distibutions associated with the contact by utilizing the multifunctional materials and strutural models we have developed.


Last Modified: 12/13/2017
Modified by: Hugh A Bruck
